div.p:
Ex quoniam demonstratum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 1
, etc. This is distinction 37 in which, after the Master treated how things are in the divine science, now he shows how God is in the essence of every creature. And this is divided in three because in the first place regarding the being of God in things he lists some modes and approves of the true modes, in the second place he disproves false modes, in third place he confirms manifest what he says. The second begins at
cumque divina natura
Lombardus, Sent., I, d .37, c. 5
. The third begins at
fateamur itaque
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 9
.

Regarding the first, he does two things because in the first place he shows how God is in some things in a special way through grace, in the second place how he is in some things generally through nature. The second begins at
ex praedictis patet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 37, c. 3
. The first part is divided into two parts because in the first place he shows that God dwells in holy men, in the second place he responds to some doubts. The second begins at
ex praedictis patet si autem quaeris
Lombardus, Sent. d. 37, c. 3, XXX
, etc.

The following question is asked, whether the divine or necessary principle in every being is a necessary being; whether just as God is the true and infallible idea of everything, so also every thing is locus of the capacity of God himself, though changeable?

That not because it would follow that God would not be able in some situations to act at a distance. The consequent is false because then an agent acts more quickly on something near at hand than something further removed. With the supposed disposition the consequence is clear, if God is everywhere, it follows no thing is locally at a distance from God. This is confirmed because it is the case that God is everywhere according to power and not according to essence, therefore.

In the second place, God is able to acquire a certain place, therefore God is not fixed in every place. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear both because God is able to be in a place or in a creature in which he is not, and also because it is possible that some being is not the locus of God because no created being is a necessary being.

In the third place, God is not present everywhere, therefore. The antecedent is clear in the first place God is able to begin to be anywhere, for having supposed that were to destroy every created place and then afterward were to recreate it, then in this case he would begin to be everywhere. Secondly because is not an inspiration or an empty imagined thing. Thirdly because the God-man is not everywhere, therefore God is not everywhere. The consequence holds because every God-man is man, and the antecedent is proved because God is not everywhere man, otherwise some body would de facto be in an infinity of places.

In opposition is the
Master in this distinction
XXX
. And this is confirmed because to be everywhere is a type of perfection, therefore it should be attributed to God. The consequence is clear. The antecedent is seen in the Master in the text.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: it is not the case that God is in a created thing through his own power that he himself is not in the same thing through is own essence. This is proved through the
Master, in this distinction 37, chapter 2 , saying
God is in all things and is always everywhere because to be everywhere proper to the deity.
Lombardus, XXX . Nevertheless note that according to
Giles, in his treatise on the body of Christ, theorem 5 , he says,
though it belongs to the deity to be in every place, nevertheless he is not determined to a place nor defined or circumscribed in a place
Aegidius Romanus, xxx . The same thing is said by the
Master
XXX .

First corollary: that if the divine power is not apart from any being or place, then it is sufficiently inferred that the essence is everywhere, contra
Scotus, in this distinction
Scotus, I, d. xxx . This is clear because the divine essence and power are the same.

Second corollary: though a created agent is able to act in some space
removed from itself by a certain distance, nevertheless the uncreated agent is not able to act or produce something through its omnipotence in any space or distance removed from itself The first part is clear from the illuminating sun given that there are parts of air distant from it and it produces heat in these parts. The second part is proved because is intimately present to every being and position, since this is proper to him
according to the Master
Lombardus, I, d. xxx .

Third corollary: though de facto to be present in every location attinctive does not properly belong to any created thing, nevertheless some created mutable things is able to be in every place contentive. The first is clear because to be everywhere attinctive through power and essence is proper to the deity alone, therefore. The second part is proved because let it stand that every created place other than the one in which I currently am be annihilated, in such a case it follows that I am everywhere and in every place.

The second conclusion: just as God does not lack his being in any created place, so God contains no place determinately. This is proved because to lack place is the proper disposition or condition of that which has been placed, therefore God is not properly contained in any place nor is he locatable. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear. The second part is proved because to be properly contained in space is to be terminated and exceeded by some space. But no place terminates or is able to exceed God, therefore.

The first corollary: though place, time, and situation are affirmed or said about God in a translated sort of way, nevertheless the modes by which God is in creatures are in someways distinguished The first is clear from
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 8 , when he says,
but to be situated and had in space and in time are not properly, but translatively and through likenesses, said about God
Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, 8, 9
. The second part is proved through
Gerard of Siena, in the first book, in distinction 37, in article 2
Gerardus de Senis, Sent. I, d. 37, a. 2
because to be in according to essence is nothing other than to attain this other according to its essence such that between the essence of one and the essence of the other no intervening mediating distance occurs between these essence. And this leads back to the
second corollary of the first conclusion
, but to be according to presence is to attain something according to knowledge and foreknowledge, but to be in something according to power is to be in some mode according to a conserving operation.

The second corollary: it is as repugnant to God to be defined, moved, or changed in place as it is that there is some created being and that God is not intimately present with it. This is clear because according to
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 3 , he says,
no things would be changeably good unless there were something unchangeably good.
Augustine, De Trinitate, VIII, 3, 5
. This is confirmed because to be defined or circumscribed in place is to terminate in place or to exceed something that has been placed.

Third corollary: it stands that God is in one mode only unchangeable in himself and that he is changeable in creatures in many or multiple modes. This is clear because God in diverse created things produces diverse and multiple effects, therefore. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because he produces one effect in a rational creature and another in a brute creature. The consequence is clear because that God is in creatures connotes an effect of God in these things. For this conclusion and corollaries see
Alanus in De maximis theologiae, regula 38
Alanus de Insulis, De Maximis Theologiae, rule 38
, where he says a collection of the creator to creatures according to which the creature is in the creatures as if an efficient cause in its effects, where it is said in a comment, for when it is said that God is everywhere, this is not thus said as if it is understood that he is circumscribed in a place but rather is a way of indicating the immensity of God and that all things are contained within his immensity rather than that he is understood to be in places.
Again in rule 39
Alanus de Insulis, De Maximis Theologiae, regula 39
, when spatial statements are predicated of God either the divine immensity or the gathering of grace or the union is understood. Where a concept indicates, when God is every place, here the divine immensity is predicated, when it is aid that God is in the saints the collection of divine grace is signified, for in the saints is said to be through grace, but when it is said in the assumed man, here is predicated the union, such that there is the sense that human nature is united in Christ. These says are the sayings found there.

Third conclusion: thought it is necessary that God is in any created thing, nevertheless God has being in a body or place contingently. The first part is clear because it does not the case that the created being exists and that God does not conserve it or that God is not intimately present to it. The second part is proved because one is able to annihilate this place, there God contingently has being in this place.

The first corollary: just as it is necessary that God is in anything which is, while it is, so God does not truly have being in anything that is not. The first part is clear through what has been said. The second part is proved because, if this were true, it would follow that this would be and not be. The consequent implies a contradiction. The consequence is clear because that God is in anything or in something this is attained through his essence, knowledge, and operation, as is clear through what has been said.

The second corollary: just it is not the case that place is and that God is apart from this place, so it is not the case that some place does not exist and that God is present there or that his being is in this place. The first part is clear because that God is in some place is something he attains through his operation, but he does not operate nor conserve non-being, therefore.

The second corollary: though God is necessarily everywhere or in some place, nevertheless God is not beyond the heavens in an imaginary vacuum. This is clear from the preceding corollary. This is confirmed because is not in that which pure nothingness, but a vacuum is precisely this type of thing, otherwise it would not be a vacuum, therefore.

The third corollary: just it is the case that ceases to be everywhere, so it is not repugnant for God to be everywhere. This is clear because God is able to destroy every place and every created thing and to create it again, by which having been posited the proposed follows. From which it is clear that God or the first necessity is often able to be everywhere. This is clear because from eternity God was not everywhere, therefore. The consequence is clear because just as God began to be everywhere through creation, so he is able to annihilate everywhere and create it again.

With respect to the corollary, just as the fact that God is often everywhere does not imply he is composed or composable, so that God moves from place to place, from time to time, does not imply that he varies. This is clear because the same ratio applies in both cases. For this the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued because God is able to produce something outside of heaven, therefore he is there through his power, but he is not in that same place through his essence. Therefore it is the case that God is everywhere through his power but not through his essence.
Against the second corollary, it would follow that God would be of less perfection than a created agent. Proof, to be able to act at a distance is a type of perfection.

Against the same, the divine will is able to wish something distant from itself, therefore the divine power is able to produce something distant from itself. The consequence holds because the will and power are formally the same, and the antecedent is clear.

Against the second conclusion and corollaries, God is able to be in some way in a place he previously was not, and he is able also not to be where he previously was, therefor God is moveable and changeable. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because, if b should be destroyed, then God is not there any more, and likewise, if a new place should be created, then God will be newly present in that place. This is confirmed because, if God now destroyed the highest heaven, God would not be where the highest heaven now is, therefore he is able to not be in the place where he is. Again, if God were to cause some body outside of heaven, God would be in that same place, and yet he is not currently there, therefore.
But immediately it would be able to be said here that this will not be through a change of God himself, but a change of the newly created body outside of heaven.

Against this, it is argued because to move locally is to be now in some place and earlier be in one place or another. But this body since it was previously nothing, it neither was earlier in some place nor did it come to be
newly in this place outside heaven, therefore God is moved locally and determinately this place, which is what has been proposed. This is confirmed because, if God is not there except through body newly created there, it follows that the created body is naturally there before God. The consequent is false because it follows that the body would be able to be created there without God being there because what is naturally prior is able to be without that which is posterior. Again God is naturally in a place prior to acting there.

Against the first part of the third conclusion and its corollaries, it is argued, if God is not in empty space outside of heaven and is able to be there without the positioning of a new body, it follows that God is changeable and moveable locally. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because this kind of transition from not being there to being there is not able to be without change in God or in something else. But the fact tat God is there without a new position etc. is proved because in such an imaginary space God is ale to place an angel with a created body and then is able to annihilate this body while conserving the angel, just as if God were to annihilate the air existing in this house while conserving us here.

In the second place, before the creation of the world God was present to any imaginable space outside heaven, therefore. The antecedent is proved because that God acts in any created space presupposes that God is there since God was able to create the world before he created it. Similarly, he is able to create a world outside the highest heaven, therefore.

In the third place, God knows distinctly and intuitively the infinity of space outside heaven, therefore he is present in this space. The consequence is clear because everything understood by God is actually present to God unless it is in potency only, but this space outside heaven exists de facto, therefore.

In the fourth place, through
Blessed Augustine, V De civitate Dei, chapter , where against those asking why God began to create the world in this determinate time when earlier he had ceased for an infinite amount of time, and through this mode of objection he responds saying that
in the same way it is able to be asked why in this space of the world did he determinately create the world, since outside this world infinite space stands open on every side
, and below that
if they say that the substance of God is absent from so many expanses of places outside the world and is present only in that one very small place in which the world is now occupied, this is inconvenient and empty speech
. These are things Augustine says, from which the proposed seems to follow.

In the fifth place, let it be put that a is the site of the world and b is a similar imaginary site outside of and at a distance from heaven, and let God move the world from site a to site b situating the world in b, then it is asked, either God was earlier in site b or was not. If he was, then the proposed is had. If he was not, then by the same reason God is not now in site a, therefore God has removed himself from a and added himself to b, therefore God has moved locally, which is false. Therefore it follows that, just as God is now in site a so he was earlier in site b.

To the first, it is said that it is improperly said that God is able to act in some where which is outside heaven because outside of heaven is not some where nor a there or a place. In the second place, it would become possible that there is a difference between these statements, God is able to act there and God is able to act. In the third place, it would be able to be said that wherever God is able to act, there is the presence of the divine essence.

To the second, the consequence is denied because, though in limited causes not being able to act at a distance proceeds from imperfection, nevertheless in unlimited causes it proceeds from a perfection, namely from the divine immensity and simplicity and immobility.

To the third, it is said that the divine will is not able to will something distant from itself on account of its immensity and simplicity and immobility, as
is said above.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequence is denied as before. And to the proof it is said that something is where it was not before is able to occur in two ways. In the first mode through arrival of that thing to a preexisting place. In the second through a new position of the thing into being or the creation of that which is the place. In the second mode, God is able to be present newly in a place and to cease to be in a place, not through change of God, but of the thing which is the place. And thus it is clear that God does not properly leave a place nor has he deserted a place, but place has deserted God because it has ceased to be.
To the reply, it is said that, though this body does not change from place to place, nevertheless it changes because it has passed from non-being to being absolutely, and this suffices.

To the second reply, it is said that God is not there through is body nor through ratio of body. if it is some causality in the body with respect to God is noted, but if necessarily is noted commonly, then it is said that the God being is there neither before nor after the body, but according to the natural understanding the bodily being and the divine being are there before the God being is present to the body or in place

For which it should be noted that in this imaginary space outside heaven he is not there or elsewhere except potentially because it is possible that there is a magnitude there in which he would be formally one thing and another thing there.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that, if it is understood without a new position in the present or the past, then the second part. The antecedent should be denied. But if it is understood with out a new position of a present existing body, then the consequence is denied. And to the proof it is said tat if God becomes presen there, then there will be some present or past change with respect to body. But to the proof of the second part of the antecedent, when it is said let there be put there God, an angel, etc., it is said that this only proves that God is able to be there when having posited some created being outside of heaven. Either this remains or it does not, but it does not follows from this that he is able to be now outside heaven when no created being has been posited there at the same time or before, though an angel is able to be immediately placed ther by God because change is able to occur with respect to the angel but not with respect to God, just as God is not able to change from not loving b to loving b without change in b itself. And this is not an imperfection in God but a perfections because this comes from the unchangeability of God, on account of which such a transitions of a contradiction is not able to occur with respect to him without a change being made in something else.

In the second place, it is said that God is not said to be outside of heaven in an imaginable space because there nothing is nor was nor will be, and it would be in vain to posit that God exists through infinite space in which no action is ever undertaken.
To the second, the antecedent is denied because this space was pure nothing, as was said, but God existed in his very self.

In the second place, it is said that it should not be posited that God acts in an act outside of heaven unless reason or authority compels. Nor does his immensity demand this, but it demands that it is impossible that there is a place or thing outside of God and distant from him that God is not present to according to his essence, power, and intuition, and God has this from himself.

In the third place, it is said that, though through the power of God it is possible for some being to be everywhere, nevertheless this being would be apart from some existing place, and it does not have from itself the ability to be present everywhere, as God does who from his immensity is not able to be apart for any place as long as that place exists.
To the third, the consequence would be able to be denied because, just as God was not present in act at that time because nothing was, so neither is he present to this space which is nothing

To the fourth, it is said that Augustine is speaking against those who imagine that from eternity up to the beginning of the creation of the world infinite spaces of time transpired, and consequently when he asks, why God ceases in these infinite times and after this mode began in this determinate time, and he asks
about those things by imagining what is outside the world proportionally to be a space of places extending on all sides in every dimension, and according to this he asks why world was founded in this determinate part of this space more greatly than in another. Therefore, he argues against those because they have to posit an infinity of worlds through the same argument by which they argue an infinity or eternity of the world. Therefore Augustinus speaks against those imagining space in act inasmuch as it is really a receptacle of coexisting bodies according to its parts really because nevertheless according to the truth of the matter nothing is more than a chimera.

To the firth, the thing posited is admitted, but it is said that b is not similar to this a because a is true real being and b is not.
In the second place,
dist
, I say that b is not distant from a because between being and non-being there is no distance.
In the third place, I say that God would not be ale to move the world from the site in which it is to an imaginary site. The reason is because it is impossible for motion to become acquisitive of place in a vacuum or to move to a terminus that is not a being.
Ad rationes in oppositum patet per dicta in conclusionibus solutio.

Et quoniam demonstratum est
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 37, c. 1
. The first conclusion of distinction 37: that God always existing unchangeably in himself is in every nature or essence presently, potentially, and essentially without definition and without circumscription in every place, and without change in every time, and resides in holy spirits and in animals through grace, but in the man christ he is most excellently because in him the fullness of the deity dwells corporally.

Second conclusion: that where God dwells there God is, nevertheless not everywhere is the place that he dwells, for just as the whole soul of Adam is in the same moment in every part of his body and it is not less present in lesser members and nevertheless in some parts it acts more intensely and in other parts less intensely, so God is everywhere but in the saints especially and in those in whom he dwells he is said to exist in a special way as in a temple, but there are the wicked also and if God, who is never absent, is there where they are, nevertheless they are not with him, therefore it is said our father who is in heaven, (that is in the saints in whom he is in a special way namely through grace) but is not everywhere.

Third conclusion: that God before things were was in himself. Whence God is in himself and in things, for the said are not called the house of God, such that when these are removed God would fall away but it is said that God dwells in the saints, such that, if he were to withdraw they would fall away and be deficient.

Fourth conclusion: that God is a dweller of some not knowing God, such as children reborn through baptism, and dweller of some knowing God, such as the blessed who are loving God, but of some knowing he is not a dweller, such as the wicked who know him but do not love him, for they do not belong to the temple of God who knowing God do not in the same way glorify God.
Fifth conclusion: just as the rays of the sun are not contaminated by dirt, so the divine essence existing every where is not stained by any thing sordid.

Sixth conclusion that every body is a locale and divisive in place and according to time. But the created spirit is a local, but not divisive, but determinative, for so it is here because it is not found elswhere and its moved according to place and according to time since it undergoes changes of joy, pay, knowledge, and oblivion. But is God is not a locale and uncircumscribable existing everywhere in totality because he is moved neither according to time nor place, but is entirely unmovable.
